item.title: How AI fixed my procrastination
item.description: I struggled to get started. For ages, I kept putting off building this website, creating a new programming language for Visual Studio, and coming up with fresh color themes. Each project looked overwhelming, and I couldn‚Äôt find the time or motivation to jump in. It all just felt like too much at once. But when a national holiday gave me a Link to article: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/visualstudio/how-ai-fixed-my-procrastination

item.title: All the other cool languages have try...finally. C++ says "We have try...finally at home."
item.description: Many languages¬π that have exceptions also have a finally clause, so you can write try { ‚ü¶ stuff ‚üß } finally { always(); } A quick checks shows that this control structure exists in Java, C#, Python, JavaScript, but not C++. C++ says, "We have try...finally at home." Link to article: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/oldnewthing/20251222-00/?p=111890

item.title: Azure Developer CLI (azd) Dec 2025 - Extensions Enhancements, Foundry Rebranding, and Azure Pipelines Improvements
item.description: Welcome to the December 2025 edition of the Azure Developer CLI (azd) release blog‚Äîour final release of the year! This post covers releases 1.22.0 through 1.22.5, wrapping up 2025. To share your feedback and questions, join the December release discussion on GitHub. Link to article: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/azure-sdk/azure-developer-cli-azd-december-2025

item.title: Work item linking for Advanced Security alerts now available
item.description: Security vulnerabilities don't fix themselves. Someone needs to track them, prioritize them, and actually ship the fix. If you've ever tried to manage security alerts alongside your regular sprint work, though, you know the friction: you're looking at an alert in one tab, switching to your backlog in another, trying to remember which vulner Link to article: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/devops/work-item-linking-for-advanced-security-alerts-now-available

item.title: A shortcut gives me a weird path for a program shortcut that doesn't point to the executable, so what is it?
item.description: Say you have a shortcut file and you want to see what its target is. The natural thing to do is to call IShellLink::GetPath, which returns S_FALSE if the shortcut does not target a path, or returns S_OK and a path to the target. But for some shortcuts, it returns S_OK but produces a Link to article: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/oldnewthing/20251219-00/?p=111885

item.title: AI Coding Agents and Domain-Specific Languages: Challenges and Practical Mitigation Strategies
item.description: Introduction AI coding agents/assistants such as GitHub Copilot have become common in modern software engineering workflows. Their strengths‚Äîrapid pattern completion, context-aware suggestions, and the ability to learn style from local code‚Äîstem from broad training on large corpora of public, general-purpose code. item.title: Celebrating 10 Years of DirectX 12
item.description: DirectX12 shipped in 2015 with a simple goal: give developers more control so games run faster, look better, and scale across Windows PC and console. Over the last decade, DirectX 12 delivered on that promise. We added features and made it easier for developers to focus on gameplay & graphics by providing more flexibility and achievable pe Link to article: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/directx/celebrating-10-years-of-directx-12
